intro: Oxytropis alberti-regelii, commonly known as the Alberti's locoweed, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, compound leaves. The plant produces yellow to reddish-purple flowers in late summer, which are clustered in racemes. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and open grasslands. Oxytropis alberti-regelii is adapted to withstand harsh climatic conditions, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
